subject: Redfish Aggregation: Router to satellite resources
commitMessage:
Redfish Aggregation: Router to satellite resources

Adds ability to route requests to either native resources or
resources that belong to a satellite BMC as part of Redfish
Aggregation.  A prefix in the URI denotes if the resource is actually
from a satellite BMC.  Prefixes are only used to denote satellite
resources.  The URI of resources on the local/aggregating BMC will
remain unchanged.

Prefixes are separated from the resource ID by an underscore.  This
means that underscores cannot be used in the prefix name itself.
The prefixes used by satellite BMCs are revealed via D-Bus as well as
the config information needed to connect to that BMC.

Requests for satellite resources will be handled locally and also
forwarded to the satellite.  The prefix should result in the local
BMC wanting to return a 404 since that resource should not exist.
That will get overridden by the satellite BMC's response to the
forwarded message.

Care should be taken to not name any local resources in a way that
could cause a collision (e.g. having a Chassis object named
"aggregated0_1U" on the aggregating BMC).  A future patch is planned
which will prevent collisions by adding the prefix "main_" to denote
resource IDs.

The patch only covers routing requests.  Requests to collection URIs
like /redfish/v1/Chassis will only return resources on the local BMC.
A future patch will cover adding satellite resources to collections.

Also note that URIs returned in the responses will not have the proper
prefix included.  Fixing these URIs will be addressed in future
patches.

A number of TODO comments are included in the code to indicate that
this functionality (collections and URI fixup) still needs to be
implemented.

Example URIs w/o Redfish Aggregation:
/redfish/v1/Chassis/1U/
/redfish/v1/Systems/system/
/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/

Example URIs after enabling Redfish Aggregation if the associated
resources are located on the local/aggregating BMC:
/redfish/v1/Chassis/1U/
/redfish/v1/Systems/system/
/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/

Example URIs if resources are instead located on a satellite BMC
named "aggregated0":
/redfish/v1/Chassis/aggregated0_1U/
/redfish/v1/Systems/aggregated0_system/
/redfish/v1/Managers/aggregated0_bmc/

Tested:
I was able to query supported resources located on the local BMC
as well as on a satellite BMC.  Requests with unknown prefixes return
a 404.  Requests to resource collections only return the resources
that are located on the aggregating BMC.

Signed-off-by: Carson Labrado <clabrado@google.com>
Change-Id: I87a3deb730bda95e72ecd3144ea40b0e5ee7d491

same as line number 277
This function is now static
ACK
Delete this
Done

Setting this patch as WIP until I address the following concern:

Per offline discussions with Ed, I should not be adding hooks to this file.  I should look towards the setUpRedfishRoute() functions in redfish-core/include/query.hpp instead.

The new approach is to add the aggregation check to setUpRedfishRouteWithDelegation() since that is ultimately called by all endpoints.  The aggregating BMC will handle all requests including those that are meant for a satellite BMC.  The paths in those requests should be unrecognized and result in setting AsyncResp to return a 404.

At the same time, an async check is being performed to determine if the request should be forwarded to a satellite BMC.  It is assumed that in those scenarios the local BMC will have set AsyncResp to return a 404.  We will overwrite AsyncResp with the resulting response returned from the satellite BMC.  

Because of the async check, we won't be able to require "main_" to denote local BMC resources.  There is a chance of a collision if the ID of a local BMC resource includes the prefix associated with a satellite BMC (such as "aggregated0_").  In practice this is unlikely.  Discussions around this point took place in the Discord (https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/855566794994221117/978728928728457256)

Note that collection requests will only return local resources.  I'll leave correctly adding the collection requests to a subsequent patch.
Cody is looking into something similar, please do your best to work together (in upstream) to accomplish both your goals.
Hi Cody, what is the feature you're looking into? Is there a WIP patch I can take a look at?
Is this true in the aggregation case?  In theory we shouldn't be seeing 404 anywhere?

> Is this true in the aggregation case?
Yes, because the aggregating BMC only knows if a request is meant for a satellite, not whether the requested resource exists on that satellite.  

> In theory we shouldn't be seeing 404 anywhere?
In theory a user should not request a 404, but it could happen due to something like typos while making manual queries.  If it does happen then the aggregator should just return the 404 from the satellite right away.  Otherwise we would exhaust the retry policy and return a 502.

> > Is this true in the aggregation case?
> Yes, because the aggregating BMC only knows if a request is meant for a satellite, not whether the requested resource exists on that satellite.  
> 
> > In theory we shouldn't be seeing 404 anywhere?
> In theory a user should not request a 404, but it could happen due to something like typos while making manual queries.  If it does happen then the aggregator should just return the 404 from the satellite right away.  Otherwise we would exhaust the retry policy and return a 502.


Damn, this is another good reason we probably need to abstract the retry logic for each client.  EventService can't continue if it got 404, and should continue to retry.  Alternatively, we could add a flag to the retry policy to say if 404 is acceptable, but that kind of starts to get hacky.

I'm fine with either solution, but as written, pretty sure this breaks retry behavior on EventService.

I don't want to use the flag option because there will likely be other error codes that need to be handled differently based on the application.  I will abstract the retry logic instead.

I can add a callback to the retry policy which expects a response code and returns a bool based on if the value was acceptable.  The callback for EventService's policy would perform the existing check that considers 2XX as a success.  The callback for Aggregation's policy would consider 2XX and 404 as a success.

I'll split this into its own patch while I'm at it.

> I don't want to use the flag option because there will likely be other error codes that need to be handled differently based on the application.  I will abstract the retry logic instead.
> 

SGTM.

> I can add a callback to the retry policy which expects a response code and returns a bool based on if the value was acceptable.

Slight nit, please use std::error_code or boost::system::error_code (debatable which is more correct, we have both) instead of bool so that we can post specific failure types to the client (dns resolution failure, connect failure, tls failure, ect) and add to them over time.

>  The callback for EventService's policy would perform the existing check that considers 2XX as a success.  The callback for Aggregation's policy would consider 2XX and 404 as a success.
> 
> I'll split this into its own patch while I'm at it.

Sounds good.

> Slight nit, please use std::error_code or boost::system::error_code (debatable which is more correct, we have both) instead of bool so that we can post specific failure types to the client (dns resolution failure, connect failure, tls failure, ect) and add to them over time.
Sounds good.  I opted for the latter to be consistent with the rest of the file.  That change is now covered by an earlier patch in the chain: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/54161
Yes, I should have used nullptr for that.  I'll try using weak_ptr and see if that can solves the lifetime issue.

I'm not sure if I can solve the issue by using weak_ptr.  I need the callback to own its copy of AsyncResp by shared_ptr because I need to make sure that the AsyncResp lives long enough for the callback to get called once a request is sent and a response is received.  That callback is potentially placed into a queue until the connection can take ownership of it.  

It seems like what I need to do is delete the callback (and thus the AsyncResp shared_ptr) after it gets called by the connection.  That guarantees that it stays alive only until it's used.  Without deleting the callback, it keeps AsyncResp alive even after the callback has been called.

> It seems like what I need to do is delete the callback (and thus the AsyncResp shared_ptr) after it gets called by the connection

That seems reasonable to me, and arguably something we will need to do anyway (otherwise we'll collect callback objects forever).

ideally we would move the callback out of the queue once it's used, so that we can just rely on raii, but that's probably not feasible.

> That seems reasonable to me, and arguably something we will need to do anyway (otherwise we'll collect callback objects forever).

Sounds good, in that case I'll just use nullptr like you described in your original comment.

> ideally we would move the callback out of the queue once it's used, so that we can just rely on raii, but that's probably not feasible.

Yeah the issue with leaving it on the queue is all the connections in the pool share the same queue.  That would effectively disable the connection pooling since only one connection could be active at a time.  

I could have some intermediate buffer to hold the callbacks for each connection in the pool, but then that's effectively what the current implementation is doing where each connection holds its own callback.
Lots of comments, most of them minor.
Generally any sort of "overwrite" is an anti-pattern, and leads to cases where useful data gets overwritten.  I suspect we need to have a way to make this more concrete.
This is something that needs handled.  It brings up the bigger question of "how do you know if both 404?"

Now that this file is doing more than just queries, does it make sense to move these into a more general header (ie not query.hpp).

We could maybe do this later, but it seems useful to discuss, as it might change this code a little.
don't use deadline_timer.  In almost every case you want steady_timer.
Also... I don't see deadline timer used here.  Maybe it can just be removed?
fyi, when we get the latest boost::url package through ci, this is fixed, and we can just use std::string_view everywhere.
thisReq.urlView already has the parsed uri.  We shouldn't need to parse it again.
This is a copy.
Please don't use auto here.  I personally don't recall the type returned by segments().

what does segments[3].empty() mean?  in general, we support both forms of accessing a resource (with and without the trailing slash) because it removes bugs.  I don't think this code is doing what you're intending, and would work differently dependent on a trailing slash being present.
Why do we need this?  I don't see any cases where this is called without an empty vector?
This branch is redundant and I think can be removed.
it looks like all this method is doing is just getting key names out of the unordered_map?  Could we just use the map directly in forwardRequest and remove this method?
nit, new code we tend to prefer string_view.

Please abstract this to a method on Response similar to what we do with Request.  At some point, we will need to make the Request and Response objects not #include any boost internals to improve compile times.
Please don't do this.  It is against the security rules to parse data from an outside source ignoring the encoding fields.
Is there a more specific aggregation error we can be using here?  I thought redfish added one specifically for aggregators.

This is a generalized anti pattern in bmcweb, for the reasons in the comment way up in this file.  Lets think through this and see if there's a way to have a better approach, maybe by adding to the completion handler?  Or flagging that this is coming through the 404 route?

At the very least, this also needs abstracted into some kind of clear() or clearBody() message.
Please don't completely replace the json object.  It causes bugs when things get aggregated.  use jsonValue.update() to add your keys to it.

Once again, against security guidelines.  If we couldn't parse the payload that should've been json as json, we need to return an error.  This needs thought through more for things like AdditionalDataUri, but considering I don't see handling of that in this patchset, I think we can just make this an error?
nit, put this with the rest of your code.

You're making two copies here.  One on stack, one on heap.  At a minimum, we should avoid making the extra copy.  There's a reason we don't copy request objects, because in some cases they might be quite large (as is the case in firmware updates).  Do we have a plan for handling that?

Also, I suspect some of this needs abstracted in a regular copy constructor.  A copy can't fail, so we need a copy overload for that, and we can remove the failure check entirely..
can this use std::bind_front to avoid the lambda?  It has better behavior when call stacks are involved.
